resources.string: Avg. Book Value Change Per Year (%):
Compound BV Change Per Year (%): NaN
Average Change in \nBook Value Per Year (%)
Average Yearly Dividend ($)\n(Over the next 10 years)

The intrinsic value of a stock is defined here as the amount of money that is generated over the lifetime of a business, related to the current book value. This is calculated by a summation of the dividends received and the annual compound change in book value over the next 10 years. The value obtained is discounted using the 10 year US Treasury Note (the discount rate) to obtain a value in today's money.

 To do this, input the current book value per share and the average expected change in book value per year (the compound rate). 

 A good place to start is to look at the previous 10 years and take the average yearly change in book value. However, this method works best for companies with stable earnings. The 4-Traders website has information regarding past and future projections of book values based on analyst data. The compound rate can be calculated via the Compound Rate Calculator (included).

 Input the amount of dividends received in 1 year but keep in mind this value will be used as the dividends for the next 10 years.

 The current 10 year US Treasury Note is listed on the Yahoo Finance website as the '10-Yr Bond'.

 Click 'Calculate' to obtain the intrinsic value.

Disclaimer

Calculations are based on general formulas used worldwide and accuracy is not guaranteed.

This is a modified formula of the Benjamin Graham method to account for high growth rate stocks as proposed by Jae Jun at 
 https://www.oldschoolvalue.com/blog/valuation-methods/value-stocks-benjamin-graham-formula/

 Note that Jae Jun recommends using a 20 year A corporate rate for a more conservative intrinsic value.
